title: Narrow Modern Oxford University Press 2004
content:
This is from the cover of \_Character Strengths and Virtues: A Handbook and Classification\_ By Christopher Peterson, Martin Seligman, Oxford University Press 2004

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317154702im_/http:/typophile.com/files/_UnknownNarrowSerifOrig_4917.jpg)

I cleaned up the letters

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317154702im_/http:/typophile.com/files/_UnknownNarrowSerifSM3_4770.jpg)
and sent them to What The Font. Its closest suggestion was Bob Alonso's Fashion Didot 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317154702im_/http:/typophile.com/files/FashionDidotAsChar_4934.gif)
  [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bagraphics/fashion-didot/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317154702/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bagraphics/fashion-didot/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bagraphics/fashion-didot/")

Close, but not a match.

Any suggestions?

Thanks Don

comments.content:
Thank you. This is indeed an exact match.  
According to the note for the OPTI font it was "Originally a phototype by Filmotype."  
Unless there was a version with the same digital outlines by another fontmaker before OPTI produced OPTI Racer, this is presumably an original digital creation by OPTI.  
Does anyone know of a matching digital font before the OPTI font?  
I only ask because of of the notorious reputation of OPTI/Castcraft as a forger of unauthorized clones of digital fonts. A relatively small proportion of its fonts were original digital creations.  
Don

Not much help, but I can confirm from Filmotype catalog showings that this was originally Filmotype Racer. I know of no other digital versions.

Stuart Sandler bought the rights to the [Filmotype collection](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317154702/http:/old.myfonts.com/foundry/Filmotype/) in 2006 and has since been having several fontmakers create digital versions [for sale](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317154702/http:/old.myfonts.com/browse/foundry/filmotype/?PREFS_SET%5Bipp%5D=96). No Racer yet, though.

Thanks Mike for the confirmation that the OPTI Racer is indeed based on a Filmotype font with the name of Racer.  
As far as the fonts being created by Stuart Sandler's people from the Filmotype archives, I trust you will agree that the current rate of production is very slow -- only six fonts were released in 2014. [https://www.myfonts.com/foundry/Filmotype/?sort=new](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317154702/https:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/Filmotype/?sort=new "https://www.myfonts.com/foundry/Filmotype/?sort=new")  
Don

I certainly would agree, Don. And the 69 fonts digitized thus far make it clear that nobody is racing to produce the more generic sans or serifs.

I was just wanting to clarify for anyone accessing this thread in the future and wanting to use a font like this commercially that Filmotype isn't defunct; the legitimate rights belong to Stuart Sandler.

By the way, I appreciate the fact that Sandler and colleagues are including the batch of alternates that most Filmotype fonts had.

Mike, looking at the example of Racer, we have a design that Oxford University Press choose as the best way of expressing its title theme. I don't know whether OUP used the OPTI digital or a Filmotype analog source.

I find the Racer typeface design superior to Fashion Didot for this purpose.

Anyone trying something similar for a commercial project today would be stuck in the bind of using a digital font from OPTI -- an orphan foundry where there is no way of obtaining appropriate intellectual property permissions -- or making the font from scratch.

I do hope that Stuart Sandler's digitization plan has Racer in the next batch.

Cheers.

Don

Should give credit for the find. Unfortunately Mike, I can only give it to one person.  
Don
